DOC.HEAD: Noriega Remains At Large Despite U.S. Offensive; Nine Americans Dead
Eds: Inserts graf 5, ``The Pentagon xxx'' with operation given a codename; subs graf 25 with 3 grafs byplay at OAS meeting, ``At a xxx''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told the American people today that he sent American forces into a surprise overnight assault in Panama to end a ``dark chapter of dictatorship'' by Manuel Antonio Noriega and forestall a ``grave danger'' to the 35,000 Americans living there. Bush ordered American forces to apprehend Noriega so he could be put on trial in the United States on charges of drug trafficking, but he acknowledged that Noreiga remained at large. ``We will chase him and we will find him,'' vowed the nation's top military officer, Gen. Colin Powell. He said reinforcements flown to Panama and those on the way would bring the U.S. force there to 24,000. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said nine Americans were killed in action, 39 were wounded and one was missing. He said he did not know how many Panamanians had died. The Pentagon codenamed the mission ``Operation Just Cause.'' In a nationally televised Oval Office speech at 7:20 a.m. EST, a somber Bush said, ``I took this action only after reaching the conclusion that every other avenue was closed and the lives of American citizens were in grave danger,'' Bush said. The White House said the decision had been reached Sunday, after an American Marine officer was shot and killed outside Noriega's military headquarters. Bush offered this explanation: ``General Noriega's reckless threats and attacks upon Americans in Panama created an imminent danger to the 35,000 American citizens in Panama. As president, I have no higher obligation than to safeguard the lives of American citizens. And that is why I directed our armed forces to protect the lives of American citizens in Panama, and to bring General Noriega to justice in the United States.'' But while key military objectives had been achieved and most organized resistance eliminated, Bush said, ``the operation is not over yet. Gen. Noriega is in hiding.'' ``Nevertheless, yesterday a dictator ruled Panama and today constitutionally elected leaders govern,'' the president said. One intelligence source on Capitol Hill said there had been reports in recent months of a deterioration in Noriega's mental state, including increased paranoia and constant drinking. But the source cautioned that the reports were not based on hard evidence and he discounted their importance as a factor in the launching of today's military action. U.S. officials noted that leaders of a failed coup attempt last October had said Noriega had been drinking heavily and Powell said he had heard reports that Noriega had been threatening operations of the canal. After his speech, Bush signed an order lifting U.S. economic sanctions against Panama and directing ``an orderly unblocking of Panamanian government assets in the United States.'' Separately, Bush issued a memo to the Pentagon specifically authorizing U.S. forces to apprehend Noriega ``and any other persons in Panama currently under indictment in the United States for drug-related offenses'' and to turn them over to U.S. law enforcement officials. However, his declaration that Noriega had so far eludd the grasp of American forces left the overall success of the military mission in question. Bush said Guillermo Endara, who won last May's election in results that Noriega refused to accept, was hastily sworn in as president of Panama. And he said he was committed to implement the Panama Canal Treaties and surrender control of the canal to Panama in the year 2000. Bush's swift action stood in contrast to his inaction last October, when he kept U.S. forces on the sidelines while some Panamanian generals sought to oust Noriega in a coup. Bush drew heavy congressional criticism at that time. As evidence, Bush noted that Noriega last week declared his ``military dictatorship to be in a state of war with the United States.'' He also recited a series of events in Panama over the past few days, including the fatal shooting of an American military officer. ``Tragically some Americans have lost their lives in defense of their fellow citizens, in defense of democracy,'' the president said. He expressed his condolences to their families and said he regretted that some innocent Panamanians also had been killed. Bush said the forces flown overnight to Panama would be withdrawn ``as quickly as possible.'' Powell said nearly 7,000 additional soliders and paratroopers had arrived from stateside bases and 2,500 were en route this morning to supplement those troops based in Panama. Bush said he informed congressional leaders and U.S. allies about his decision. Sen. Jesse Helm, R-N.C., predicted, ``The majority of the Senate will feel good by this turn of events.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Bush's action ``was made necessary by the reckless actions of Gen. Noriega.'' But Sen. Claiborne Pell, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said, ``I would not have engaged in such unilateral or such go-it-alone action'' without the support of other Central American nations. At an emergency meeting of the Organization of American States, called at the request of Noriega's envoy, Endara issued a statement asking the organization to recognize Lawrence Chewning Fabrega as its ambassador to the OAS. The statement was faxed to the OAS from the U.S. Army South headquarters in Panama, according to the sign-off. Noriega's representative, Jose Maria Cabrera, stayed in the chair designated for his country. ``I am the representative of the Republic of Panama, and I denounce this criminal aggression,'' he told a reporter. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the administration sent a cable to Soviet officials informing them of the action. The Soviets swiftly condemned the move as a violation of the United Nations charter. Bush said the United States had tried repeatedly _ but unsuccessfully _ to use diplomacy and negotiation to remove Noriega and that it was now recognizing the ``democratically elected government.'' The president spoke after only a few hours of sleep. He had stayed in the Oval Office until a few minutes after 4 a.m. to monitor developments in Panama, and was in time for his speech that began shortly after 7 a.m. Vice President Dan Quayle, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and other top aides also were at the White House for much of the night. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Powell were in the Pentagon's military command center. Beginning with Bush, the administration did what it could to preserve secrecy of the operation before Fitzwater's dramatic announcement about the military action. The president hosted a White House Christmas party attended by reporters, but gave no hint of the impending action. U.S. military intervention in Central America is a tradition of long standing _ including President Reagan's decision to invade Grenada in 1983 and overthrow a leftist government. Bush had hinted at military action earlier in the week, when he told interviewers, ``I think a president, all presidents, have options, but they don't discuss what they might be.'' First Reagan and then Bush have been trying to force Noriega's ouster since 1988, when the Panamanian leader was indicted in this country on federal drug trafficking charges. The United States imposed stiff economic sanctions against Panama in hopes of dislodging him from power. The situation in Panama had been jumpy for days. Tuesday afternoon, the Pentagon spokesman said a U.S. soldier used an unauthorized weapon when he shot a Panamanian police officer Monday. He called the incident ``very regrettable'' but said it had to be considered in the context of a deteriorating situation.
